children.text: Let me start with the canTake function.

children.text:
In Java, it has parameters xNeeded, xAvailable, etc. The function returns true only if xNeeded <= xAvailable and yNeeded <= yAvailable. So in Fortran, I can write a function like:

LOGICAL FUNCTION canTake(xN, xA, yN, yA)
    INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: xN, xA, yN, yA
    canTake = .FALSE. IF (xN <= xA .AND. yN <= yA) THEN
        canTake = .TRUE. END
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
IF
END FUNCTION

children.text:
Like:

LOGICAL FUNCTION canTake(xN, xA, yN, yA)
    INTEGER :: xN, xA, yN, yA
    canTake = (xN <= xA) .AND. (yN <= yA)
END FUNCTION That's concise enough.

children.text: Since Fortran passes by reference usually, but here the parameters are all intent(in), so that should be okay. Moving to the main program.

Now, writing out the translated code as per above steps:

The final Fortran code would look like this:

---

PROGRAM codeforces_79A
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER :: x, y, turn
    READ(*,*) x, y
    turn = 0
    DO
        IF (MOD(turn,2) == 0) THEN !
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
Ciel's turn
            IF (canTake(0, x, 22, y)) THEN
                y = y -22
            ELSE IF (canTake(1, x, 12, y)) THEN
                x = x -1
                y = y -12
            ELSE IF (canTake(2, x, 2, y)) THEN
                x = x -2
                y = y -2
            ELSE
                PRINT*,'Ciel'
                STOP
            END IF
        END IF
        turn = turn + 1
    END DO

CONTAINS
    LOGICAL FUNCTION canTake(xN, xA, yN, yA)
        INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: xN, xA, yN, yA
        canTake = (xN <= xA) .AND. (yN <= yA)
    END FUNCTION canTake
END PROGRAM codeforces_79A

---

The main class is codeforces_79_A, and there's a method canTake which checks if certain amounts can be taken. Depending on turn's parity, different conditions are checked for taking resources.

Hmm, translating to Fortran. First, in Fortran, functions and subroutines are different from Java methods. The canTake function can probably be a function in Fortran that returns a logical (boolean). Then the main program will handle the input/output and the loop.

Let me start with the canTake function. In Java, it has parameters xNeeded, xAvailable, etc. The function returns true only if xNeeded <= xAvailable and yNeeded <= yAvailable. So in Fortran, I can write a function like:

LOGICAL FUNCTION canTake(xN, xA, yN, yA)
    INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: xN, xA, yN, yA
    canTake = .FALSE.
    IF (xN <= xA .AND. yN <= yA) THEN
        canTake = .TRUE.
    END IF
END FUNCTION

Wait, but maybe even simpler. The function can just return the logical expression. Like:

LOGICAL FUNCTION canTake(xN, xA, yN, yA)
    INTEGER :: xN, xA, yN, yA
    canTake = (xN <= xA) .AND. (yN <= yA)
END FUNCTION

That's concise enough. Since Fortran passes by reference usually, but here the parameters are all intent(in), so that should be okay.

Moving to the main program. The main reads x and y from input. In Java, it uses BufferedReader and StringTokenizer, but in Fortran, probably using read(*,*) to read two integers directly.

The variables x and y start as integers read from input. turn is initialized to 0. Let's declare those variables. Also, in Fortran, variables must be declared.

PROGRAM codeforces_79_A
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER :: x, y, turn
    ! read x and y from input

    turn = 0

        IF (MOD(turn,2) == 0) THEN

                y = y -12

        ELSE

            ELSE IF (canTake(2, x, 2, y)) THEN
                x = x -2
                y = y -2
            ELSE
                PRINT *, 'Ciel'
                STOP
            END IF
        END IF

        turn = turn +1
    END DO

END PROGRAM

---

PROGRAM codeforces_79A
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER :: x, y, turn
    READ(*,*) x, y
    turn = 0
    DO
        IF (MOD(turn,2) == 0) THEN ! Hanako's turn
            IF (canTake(2, x, 2, y)) THEN
                x = x - 2
                y = y - 2
            ELSE IF (canTake(1, x, 12, y)) THEN
                x = x -1
                y = y -12
            ELSE IF (canTake(0, x, 22, y)) THEN
                y = y -22
            ELSE
                PRINT*,'Hanako'
                STOP
            END IF
        ELSE ! Ciel's turn
            IF (canTake(0, x, 22, y)) THEN
                y = y -22
            ELSE IF (canTake(1, x, 12, y)) THEN
                x = x -1
                y = y -12
            ELSE IF (canTake(2, x, 2, y)) THEN
                x = x -2
                y = y -2
            ELSE
                PRINT*,'Ciel'
                STOP
            END IF
        END IF
        turn = turn + 1
    END DO

CONTAINS
    LOGICAL FUNCTION canTake(xN, xA, yN, yA)
        INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: xN, xA, yN, yA
        canTake = (xN <= xA) .AND. (yN <= yA)
    END FUNCTION canTake
END PROGRAM codeforces_79A

---
